Process and Chemical Safety Information

Comprehensive chemical data have been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine.  This information includes chlorine health and safety background information and SDS sheets.

Equipment safety information was meticulously compiled on the chlorine process. Specifications for chlorine process are collected and provided in one place for easy reference. Details such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; safe upper and lower pressures; and codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the processes are on file at the facility.  Mills Plant also has procedures in place that are triggered to update process safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.

 
Process Hazard Analysis 

In 1992, 1994, 1995, and 1998 detailed process hazard analyses (PHAs) were conducted for the chlorination system equipment and procedures.  The 1998 RMP PHA was further reviewed and updated in March 2004 as part of the five-year RMP Program update.  An additional PHA was conducted in February 2006 as part of the chlorine containment and scrubber modification project (i.e., Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility design and construction).  A 5-year update of the 2006 PHA was conducted in October 2011 and it will be updated again within a five-year period or whenever there is a major change in the process. The control room at the plant is manned 24 hours a day, year round.  Access to the plant is through guarded security gates, which are closed after regular hours when the plant is patrolled by security guards.  The Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility is monitored by video cameras from the control room and has door alarms.  The doors to the Chlorine Containment Building are locked using a key card badge entry system.

Finally, no chlorine releases that caused or could have caused a safety or health hazard, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place have occurred at the Mills Plant during the last five years.

Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The Mills Plant accidental release prevention program complies with all RMPR, CalARP and PSM requirements and is based on the following key elements:
	Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.
	Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
	Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.
	Performance of process hazard analysis of process, equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.
	Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment.
	Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the operators.
	High level of training of the operators and maintenance staff.
	Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.

An update of the March 1999 CalARP seismic risk assessment was completed in May 2004 based on Region 1 LEPC CalARP Seismic Update Guidance and recommendations were provided to Mills Plant staff for their evaluation and implementation.  An additional seismic risk assessment was conducted in October 2007 as part of the chlorine containment and neutralization project startup..  A 5-year update of this seismic assessment was conducted in July 2012 and recommendations have been provided to Mills Plant staff for their evaluation and implementation.

Operating Procedures

Mills Plant maintains up-to-date, accurate, written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for the chlorine process.  The Mills Plant ensures effective operating and maintenance practices by combining them with operating and maintenance training programs.  Standard operating procedures (SOPs) provide system descriptions, specifications, equipment inspection requirements, and operating procedures for the chlorine system.  The operating procedures include connection/disconnection for chlorine storage vessel, start-up and shutdown for chlorine evaporators, after maintenance start-up for chlorine evaporators, maintenance shutdown for chlorine evaporators, start-up and shutdown for ejectors, start-up and shutdown for chlorinators, chlorine system emergency shutdown, start-up following an emergency shutdown, and temporary operations.  Also included are the maintenance and troubleshooting procedures, including consequences of deviation and the steps to correct or avoid deviations. Mills Plant updates procedures annually or whenever a change occurs that alters the steps needed to operate safely.  Such an update of operating procedures took place to incorporate changes in chlorine operation associated with the chlorine containment and scrubbing system modification.  Updated operating procedures will be developed and put in place pri

or to any new process equipment coming on line or changes made in the handling of chlorine equipment, and reconfiguration of the facilities.

 
Training 

Mills Plant employees presently involved in operating or maintaining the chlorine process are trained in an overview of the process and detailed applicable operating and maintenance procedures. Mills Plant ensures that each employee newly assigned to the process, is trained and tested to be competent in the operating procedures listed pertaining to their duties.  Mills Plant training program includes four elements: (1) initial training and awareness training, (2) refresher training, (3) documentation, and (4) testing.  Each employee presently involved in operating the chlorine process has been trained to receive the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities, including chlorine leak response, as provided in the operating procedures.  

Refresher training is provided every three years or less to each employee operating the covered process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  In addition, the Mills Plant ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after a major change as indicated in their Management of Change and/or Pre Startup Safety Review procedures.  Such an update of chlorine operations training took place together with the update of chlorine operating procedures to incorporate changes in chlorine operations associated with operating the chlorine containment and scrubbing system modification.

Mills Plant prepares and retains records of initial and refresher training, which includes the identity of the employee, the date of training, and the signature of the person (s) administering the training.

Contractors

Mills Plant has procedures and policies in place that ensure that contractors are properly informed of the hazards, access limitations

to these process areas, and emergency response procedures, and are prepared to safely complete the work.  The contractors are informed, prior to the initiation of the work at the site, of the applicable provisions of the Emergency Action Plan.  Mills Plant holds contractor safety briefings before allowing them near or in the process area; controls access to the process areas, and evaluates the contractor's safety performance.

Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program

Mills Plant ensures that a pre-startup safety review is completed for any new process covered by this regulation, or for significant modifications to an existing covered process that requires a change in the process safety information.  Mills Plant maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment.  Mills Plant mechanical integrity program includes the following:

	Written procedures for maintaining mechanical integrity through inspection and testing of process equipment, based on instructions of equipment vendors, industry codes and practice, and prior operating experience.
	Implementation of the written procedures by performing inspections and tests on process equipment at specified intervals.
	Training of maintenance personnel in preventive maintenance program procedures; safe work practices such as lockout/tagout, line or equipment opening, and avoidance and correction of unsafe conditions; and safe use and application of special equipment and/or unique tools.

The Mills Plant mechanical integrity program was updated to reflect all changes associated with the chlorine containment and scrubbing system modification.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California (MWD) distributes drinking water to member water agencies throughout Southern California.  MWD provides approximately 60 percent of the drinking water used by nearly 16 million people living on the southern California coastal plain between Ventura County and the Mexican border.

Disinfection is a critical process used by MWD in the treatment of its drinking water.  Disinfection helps to protect public health by killing pathogens in the water and preventing the spread of waterborne diseases.  The use of chlorine as a disinfectant in the treatment of drinking water and wastewater has been the dominant disinfection method in the United States since it was introduced, around the beginning of this century.  MWD currently utilizes bulk chlorine for disinfection at all of its water treatment plants, including the Henry J. Mills Water Treatment Plant (Mills Plant).

As one might expect from its superior disinfection properties, chlorine is a hazardous substance.  Thus, storing and handling chlorine can present a risk to employees and the public without proper precautions.  MWD regards safe practices in the storing and usage of chlorine to be of primary importance and has an excellent safety record with chlorine.  To further safe practices, MWD has constructed a Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility at Mills Plant to contain all chlorine inside a building which is protected by vapor scrubbers.

Mills Plant's chlorine storage and usage process is subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program Rule (RMPR) and also to the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program regulation.  Both of these regulations require submission of a Risk Management Plan (RMP).  An integral part of the RMP is a summary of policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility, including a description of the possible consequences in case of an accident and the a

ctions, which will be taken, by the facility in an emergency.

The following information is specifically required in the RMP Executive Summary: 
	Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.
	General facility and regulated substances information.
	Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.
	Five-year accident history summary.
	Emergency response program summary.
	Planned changes to improve safety.

An RMP for the Mills Plant Chlorination Facility has been prepared and is being submitted to the EPA and Riverside City Fire Department in June 2014, to comply with the five-year RMP update requirement

The information required in the RMP Executive Summary is provided below for the Chlorine System at the Mills Plant.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The MWD accidental release prevention policy for chlorine involves a unified approach that integrates proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  All applicable procedures of the State of California and EPA's RMP Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response.  The Mills Plant has an excellent safety record with chlorine use.

General Facility and Regulated Substance Information

The Henry J. Mills Water Treatment Plant (Mills Plant) is located at 550 E. Alessandro Boulevard in Riverside Hills, California.  The plant is situated west of Interstate Highway 215 and south of State Highway 60.  The facility was constructed in 1978 and covers approximately 256 acres.  The plant is designed to treat drinking water, including disinfection with chlorine.  The facility currently stores and uses chlorine, a regulated toxic substance under the RMPR and CalARP Program rules, as well as the Federal and California Occupati

onal Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standards.

The Chlorine System at the Mills Plant is composed of the following components: (1) a totally contained chlorine feed system to receive, store, and deliver liquid chlorine to the evaporators, chlorine expansion vessels, associated piping and valving, leak sensors and monitors, and instrumentation, (2) totally contained evaporators to convert the chlorine to gas for use in the chlorinators (evaporator units, associated piping and valving, instrumentation), (3) totally contained chlorinators to regulate flow of chlorine gas under vacuum to the ejectors (chlorinator units, associated piping and valving, instrumentation), (4) ejectors to mix the chlorine gas with service water and inject chlorine solution at application points throughout the plant, and (5) chlorine gas treatment systems for capture and neutralization of an accidental chlorine release in the contained areas (scrubbers, caustic soda, fans, pumps, and associated piping and valving).

The chlorine storage vessels (cargo tanks) are totally contained in the Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility storage bays.

The process flow for the Chlorine System begins at the liquid chlorine angle valves located on the storage vessels in each storage bay, connected by flexible metallic hose to the fixed piping system.  Liquid chlorine is transferred by its own pressure from an on-line storage vessel in each storage bay to one or more evaporators in each evaporator room.

Each evaporator uses an electrically heated water bath to vaporize the liquid chlorine.  The chlorinators regulate the flow of chlorine gas (under vacuum) through venturi eduction to the ejectors.  The ejectors are located at various points throughout the facility, and introduce chlorine (under vacuum) into service water to form chlorine solution that subsequently mixes with the water supply at different stages of the treatment process for disinfection pu

rposes.

The Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility is continuously monitored in the control room by video cameras and chlorine leak detectors. Chlorine leak detectors are provided in the storage bays, evaporator rooms, chlorinator room and pipe tunnels.  Based on the concentration and location of chlorine detected, the leak detection system will activate a succession of safety measures, beginning with visual and audible alarms, the start-up of the chlorine neutralization system and shut down of the normal ventilation system, and finally, automatically closing storage vessel liquid chlorine angle valve.  The alarms are annunciated at the chlorine alarm panel as well as at the operator's console in the control room.  Once alerted, fully trained personnel will respond to assess the chlorine leak.  In addition, each storage vessel valve connecting to the process is provided with a remotely actuated (pneumatic) emergency shutoff system.  In case of a major chlorine leak, chlorine supply can be stopped almost instantaneously by actuating the shutoff system, automatically or manually from any of three control panels: unloading platform, chlorine maintenance room, or control room.  Emergency showers and eyewash stations are also provided throughout the Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility including the scrubber system.

A packed-bed chlorine gas scrubber system, consisting of two parallel scrubber units, is provided to neutralize an accidental release of chlorine gas from either storage bay, evaporator room, or the chlorinator room.  Caustic soda (~20% concentration) is used as the scrubbing media.

The chlorine pressure reducing valves, leak detectors, safety systems and computer control system are connected to the uninterruptible power supply (UPS) system.  In the event power is lost at the Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility, an alarm will alert the control room.  The water treatment plant has an emergency generator system, which provides backup p

rogram to ensure hot work is monitored and conducted safely on or near a process involving chlorine.

Mills Plant provides a system and approach to maintain and implement any management of change or modifications to process, equipment, procedures, chemicals, and processing conditions.  This system allows Mills Plant staff to identify and review safety hazards or provide additional safety, process, or chemical information to existing data before the proposed change would either compromise system safety or need training to be completed.

Internal Compliance Audits

Internal compliance audits are conducted every 3 years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in the RMP.  The Mills Plant assembles an audit team that includes personnel knowledgeable in the Risk Management Program rule and in the process.  This team evaluates whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the Risk Management Program rule and whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the process.  The results of the audit are documented, and a plan is developed to resolve the recommendations and implement appropriate enhancements to the prevention program.  

Incident Investigation

Mills Plant investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release (serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment) so that similar accidents can be prevented.  If required, an investigation team is assembled and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process enhancements are implemented.  Information found during the investigation is reviewed by affected staff and added or used to revise operating and maintenance procedures.  There have been no such incidents involving the Mills Plant chlorine system.

Five-year Accident History Summary

No chlorine releases that caused or c

ould have caused safety or health hazard (deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place) occurred at the Mills Plant during the last five years.

Emergency Response Program Summary

Mills Plant is a non-responding facility and, as such, does not have an emergency response plan.  Mills Plant has Technician Level HAZWOPER-trained plant employees who will respond only to incidental chlorine releases and will respond to emergency releases only to assess.  Mills Plant also includes employees trained in Incident Command System, who can coordinate with and provide technical assistance to outside emergency responders.  Depending on the severity of the accidental release, external hazardous materials response agencies, such as the Riverside City Fire Department Hazardous Materials Response Team, will be called to handle a chlorine release.  Mills Plant coordinates with local response agencies (Riverside City Fire Department) to help ensure that they are familiar with the Mills Plant Chlorine System and its emergency requirements and that it is reflected in their Area Plans.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Numerous changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were previously identified for the chlorine process in 1992, 1994, 1995, 1998 and 2004 when Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) conducted under the California Risk Management and Prevention Program (RMPP) guidelines, Process Safety Management Program and Risk Management Program were prepared for the Mills Plant.  These recommended actions have been evaluated and implemented as required.  Of the changes proposed, most prominent among them was a Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility to contain all chlorine inside a building which is protected by vapor scrubbers, a significant additional safety enhancement and risk reduction measure.
